text: CLOSE ON two eyes, closed. A YOUNG MAN, sitting up, asleep. A noise, like a slapping, not loud. Repeated, again, again. The eyes blink open. Unsure where we are. They look around. We pull back: The young man wears a jacket and tie. He sits on a bench in a subway, the car moving fast through darkness. We pull back further: The car is empty, just the young man. Bang, the noise suddenly is louder. It seems to come from the next car down. Now it goes back to the quiet slapping The young man looks at the door to the next car. He can’t see anything. The train rattles as it takes a curve. The young man gets up from the bench and takes his briefcase. He walks toward the next car, his attention on the door. ZARUMMMMM! HE SLIPS ON THE FLOOR AND FALLS ON HIS BACK. His head slams down hard, and he just lays there, decked. But his hands feel moist, his body feels wet, like he slipped in a puddle. He holds both hands up above his hea THEY’RE COVERED IN BLOOD!

head_text.subj: BLOOD POURS DOWN HIS COAT SLEEVE

text: We pull back: The young man lies in a huge lake of blood. He pulls himself up from the floor, and we see that he is soaked in blood, like he’s had a bath in it. He shivers. The next shock: A blood pool at the door to the next car. The young man approaches the door carefully, almost slidi a second time. He moves more slowly, creeping up to the door. The window of the door is covered in blood. The young man cannot see through it. He has to get closer, right up to it. His eyes move next to the glass, which reflects red on h POV through the window: We see a huge dark figure, holdin an immense mallet. The figure brings the mallet down, again and again and again, repeatedly pounding, blood hitting the glass in splashes. The young man backs away. He looks around. Outside the train, pitch black. No one else is around. He looks behind him. The car on the other side is dark, empty, no one there. Now the young looks back at the window. The glass is black. But there is something there -- A HUGE EYE staring straight back at us. IT’S THE DARK FIGURE LOOKING STRAIGHT AT US. The young man is horrified, his expression total terror.
CLOSE ON subway windows as they fly past. We stay close enough to see what looks like sides of meat hanging insid

head_text.subj: AND A DARK FIGURE IS DRAGGING SOMEONE THROUGH THE SUBWAY

text: IN SLOW MOTION, a young man walks down a sidewalk, and, a he walks, he lifts a camera. He stops and turns toward us He aims directly at the camera and shoots. LEON KAUFMAN, late 20's, hair unruly, face unshaven, eyes piercing, dar We leave slow motion: Leon shoikots more shots of the street. INT. LEON’S APARTMENT - DAY Mounted on a wall, a series of black and white stills: -- Busy street, cab stopped at a curb. MAN IN A SUIT, han out like a tackler, steals a cab by shoving another man. -- A HOMELESS campfire under an underpass. A disheveled homeless man comes at us with a bottle in hand. +e HF

-- A POLICE CAR pulled over by a sidewalk, TWO COPS * leaning over a guy in a leather jacket, hands behind him. -- A shot of a breathtaking GIRL, 20's, dark hair, hands hips, smiling sexily in a park, looking at us. * We pull back to reveal -- * The same girl, MAYA JONES, is reading a textbook at a kitchen table. She’s sexy in old pajamas and is wearing reading glasses. Smart as she is sexy, street smart, not just book smart. Leaning over the shot is LEON KAUFMAN. Late 20’s, his hai a mop of unruly curls, face unshaven, eyes piercing and dark. He is at the kitchen sink, the counter top filled with darkroom equipment. Leon looks at Maya, then at the photo of her in the park.
The chick in the photo’s hotter. Maya gives him a grin and a finger. He comes over. Maya goes in for a kiss - it’s a combination of passion and familiarity.
Mmm. You taste good. He comes back for a second kiss, and a third.
What are you reading? Maya tilts her head toward the textbook.
Metropolitan History.
Learn anything interesting?
This was never a good place to * walk at night. *
It’s not a good place to drive against traffic, either. Some cabbie from one of those former Soviet republics took a shortcut on a one-way street. Six car pile- up.
(excited) And you caught it?
Right place, right time.
How much did the Post give you?
We made the rent.
That’s great, Leon!

That buys me a couple days to work on my own stuff. Leon gets up and goes into the kitchen. He opens the refrigerator. Bottles clatter as he looks for a beer. We get a good look at the apartment. Total disarray, crammed with funky furniture and art pieces. Even a kitchen counter piled with camera equipment and stacks of test prints.
Things’1l be easier once I get my Master's.
I hate to break it to you, Maya, but history teachers don’t exactly rake it in.
Hey... Beer in hand, Leon closes the refrigerator.
Besides, it’s not just the money.
I know, baby. You want to be appreciated for your art. Leon knows she’s teasing him.
Is that too much to ask?
No. I know you'll get there. Might take a few more years. Leon heads over to a cupboard and pulls down a bag of chips.
I don’t know if I’ve got that much patience left.
Don’t worry, everything happens as it’s meant to be. Leon frowns. Maya looks up at the photo of her in the park.
You know what you need? A genius girlfriend who knows how to network and get your work seen by some classy gallery owner. Like, say, Susan Hoff. Maya grins. She’s been saving this.
What? You didn’t. How did you do that?
Jurgis is a friend of hers. He met her through the magazine... You're supposed to meet him at her gallery tonight after it closes.
And you held that back the whole time I stood around feeling sorry for myself? Maya nods, hugely pleased with herself.
You're going to pay for that. Leon charges her with a roar. They fall onto the couch, laughing.
The gallery is a converted warehouse, its interior entran a long ramp with brick walls leading to the main gallery space. Leon and Jurgis enter.
(quietly) Don’t mention Maya. Susan likes her artists available. Leon gives Jurgis a small smirk. He’s not worried about i

A bare, minimal space with the harshest gray concrete walls. A receptionist’s counter faces the front. Behind that, a low table with a few catalogues and art magazines On the walls are paintings by Clive Barker. SUSAN HOFF (40s) approaches from the back of the gallery. She is beautiful, razor sharp. There is an edge to everything she says.
Susan, this is Leon Kaufman.
Pleased to meet you. Susan smiles and shakes Leon's hand. He's nervous.
I looked at your work. There’s a consistency to your images.
Thank you.
Talk to me about them. Leon glances at Jurgis for a moment.
Sell yourself a little.

When I lived in Atlanta, I thought this was the promised land, where everything was possible. Then I got here. It was crushing. There aren’t dreams here. Just humanity. Not natural, and not kind. It pulls you in. It takes from you. I want to show the source of that energy. The “heart of the city.”
(wryly) The “heart of the city”?
Exactly.
Then you're failing. Leon freezes. She pauses long enough to let it sink in.

Most of the time. Susan motions with a finger for Leon to follow. She turns to a nearby table, where she flips through the images in his portfolio. In doing so she leans in close to Leon, brushing against him. She pauses on one photo: A MEAT WORKER looks up, angry and surprised, as he dumps half of calf carcass into a city trash can.
Now this....It’s not there but it’s closer. He looks....caught in the act. You exposed something. She gives him a look.
Something dirty. She closes the book.
But you need to get a lot dirtier.
Dirtier.  She looks at Leon, directly in the eyes.
You're searching for the “heart of the city”? Then you have to get under the flesh. That’s what I mean by dirty. Come back when you've done that. Leon stands silent, not sure what to say.
Leon stands in the entrance hall, still in a daze.
Is that it?
Hey, you got two minutes with Susan Hoff. Know how many people would suck off their uncles for that?
(to himself) “I’m looking for the real heart of the city.” What does that shit sound like?
Like the kid who just stepped off the bus. INT. LEON’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 8 Leon sits up in bed. Maya is curled up against him.
You know, sometimes I hate this city.
Yeah, and some times you love it. (beat) Come on, you're being too negative. She left the door open for you. That’s really encouraging.
No, it’s not fucking encouraging.  Maya smacks his chest.
Why are you so upset? Leon doesn’t say anything. Leon Leon each Leon Maya
Because you think she’s probably right.
I thought my stuff was good. Now I don’t know.
So you shoot something else.
I’m not sure.
You know how crazy that sounds? Tell me you’re not afraid of failing. That’s not it, right? looks at her. She smiles.
C'mon, what is it?
It’s not failure. I don’t know. Now I’m just not sure what I’m looking for.
You're with me. I’11 help you find it. meets her smile. They kiss slowly, and snake against other beneath the sheets. After a while, Maya pauses.
Come on, don’t tell me your dick is sulking, too. smirks.
It does what it does. tickles Leon until he has to laugh.  10 11 12 10.
You're lucky I’ve got the early shift at Otto’s tomorrow. Maya kisses him, rolls over, and closes her eyes. Leon stares vacantly at the ceiling.

A dimly lit subway car moves through the darkness. No one is on board, and there is no noise except the rumble of t train speeding down the tracks. The walls and all fixture of the car have a brushed metallic sheen, and light from the outside tunnels flashes the metal as the car rushes along. Overhead straps hang from the ceiling, and they move slightly in rhythm with the train. A flash of light reveals more of the straps: They’re not straps but sharp metal hooks, like hooks used to hang sides of beef. The train moves faster, and the hooks dance, slightly clangin Now the light changes again, and the hooks are hand strap just swinging, waving. INT. LEON’S BEDROOM -- NIGHT 10 With a start, Leon opens his eyes. Sees where he is. He carefully untangles himself from Maya, and slides out. Th train images were a nightmare. He shakes it off.
Leon is on the prowl, camera in hand. He snaps a shot, bu the street is empty. Up ahead: the entrance to the subway

Leon digs in his bag, looking for camera gear. He pulls out his Leica and sees what’s around. Only a few people. He swings the Leica up and shoots a HOMELESS MAN, plus tw other people walking behind him (MAHOGANY’S back and bag) Then, abruptly, Leon hears a small scream. He rounds the corner and sees a HIP GIRL. She’s surrounde by THREE GANGBANGERS. Two are heavyset and tattooed, one with a short scruffy beard. The LEADER is wiry freak with nervous energy. He’s got a prison-style tear-drop tattoo beneath his eye.  11.
Gotta pay the toll first, bitch.
Leave me alone, you asshole. With this, the leader hood slams her against the wall and grabs her throat with one hand. He pushes her chin up.

Then you’re going to have to pay on your knees. Leon watches from a distance. The girl is scared now. She’s totally surrounded. Laughing, the leader backs a few feet away from the girl. In that moment, she turns and looks at Leon. Her eyes mee his for the first time. Does she expect him to help? Leon pulls up his Leica and -- Snap! The camera freezes her and the hoodlum locked together in a primal urban stand-off. They look at Leon. Snap! Leon captures the Hoodlum’s surprise and anger, and the Girl’s fear and hope.
What the fuck are you doing? The Hoodlum is in his face.

Give me the camera. The Girl edges away from the gangbangers. Leon looks like he’s ready to slug the Hoodlum. He’s not even thinking about his camera, which he lowers to his side. If he could put the camera somewhere safe, he’d hit the guy.

I said give me the camera! The Leader steps forward and knocks Leon’s gear bag down. The Leader waits for a reaction. Leon holds his ground. Leon sees a surveillance camera above them. He points up the lens.  13 14 12.
You're giving the cops a good show. The Leader looks up. He glares at Leon.
You're dead, motherfucker. The gangbangers take off. Leon calls to the Girl.
You okay? The Girl, shaken, looks behind Leon to the way she came.
How long did you stand there watching me almost get my throat slit? You fucking asshole. Leon was expecting gratitude?
Thank you very fucking much. She pushes past him, running out the station to the track

CLOSE ON Leon, on the edge of the platform, shooting. CLICK. He shots the Hip Girl. CLICK. CLICK. CLICK. CLICK. Now we see what Leon has just shot -- POV on the car door: The image freezes as Hip Girl lunges in the car. A few riders inside, a hand holds the door.

The doors of the car hiss as the Hip Girl lands inside. We pull back: A LARGE HAND still holding the doors. On the hand, a BRACELET OF TWISTED SILVER. The HAND withdraws. The doors hiss shut. CLOSE ON the Girl's face as she finds a seat.  15 16 17 13.
Thanks. There's some real psychos out there tonight. Back to the LARGE HAND. We don’t see the hand’s owner. The Hip Girl sits in her seat, relaxing as the train move

The Hip Girl sits in a nearly empty car, the other passengers having departed. She’s at one end, and she’s turned away from the other end. But someone is there. At the back of the car, over her shoulder we see a LARGE MAN sitting straight, not moving. We don’t see him clearly, but he is huge. The Hip Girl doesn’t notice. CLOSE ON a LEATHER BAG, on the floor by the man. A LARGE HAND goes into the bag. It searches for something inside. The hand extracts a LARGE HAMMER from the bag. Huge. Back to the Hip Girl, who still has seen or heard nothing But now the LARGE MAN gets up and walks toward the Hip Girl, toward us. As he gets close, he brings his arm up. The LARGE MAN reaches the Hip Girl. The HAMMER above her. WHAM! The LARGE MAN swings the HAMMER down and cracks the Hip Girl’s head so hard it crunches like a soft melon.
The train roars through the underground.

INSIDE THE TRAIN - on a seat: a plastic bag neatly filled with the girls clothes. Close on: the girls lips. Still. Mahogany’s hand removes her lipstick with solvent. A loud sound of metal as the train makes a change of trac Mahogany looks up, then goes back to removing the lipstic  18 19 14. INT. LEON’S APARTMENT - KITCHEN -—- DAY 18 Maya sits on the kitchen counter amidst dark room equipment, in her underwear, legs wrapped around a standi Leon. He kisses her neck, she looks to the side, seeing - HER POV: a series of prints spread out on the counter. CLOSE ON: the images of the gangbangers and the Hip Girl. Leon keeps kissing her, but she pulls away, looking at th photos of the Hip Girl and the Gangbangers. She points to the first one, the girl in the photo staring directly at Maya, the photo is chilling.
When did you get these?
I took them last night.
You have to show these to Susan Hoff. What you said she wants. This is it.
You think so? Maya turns to face him. She is very serious.

If it’s not, I hope I never see it. INT. OTTO’S RESTAURANT - DAY 19 A trendy downtown restaurant, with small tables arranged an airy open space. On one side, a grill and a small bar. Maya serves Leon a leafy salad. He puts down his newspape Leon smile back at Maya and takes out a small package of deli paper from his bag. He unwraps it meticulously. oTTo, 40's, the diner’s eccentric and boisterous owner- operator, pauses by Leon. He gives Leon a hard look and shakes his head.  15.
Fuck no, I’m not doing that again.
C’mon, Otto, I’ll pay extra. Just toss it on the grill. Leon takes out a cold, gray tofu square from his deli wra

It’s bad for my reputation. This is the best Philly cheese steak in town. The tofu’ll fuck with my grill. How about having one of my specials instead? Otto takes two steak flanks and tosses them on his grill.
Because I have respect for my body, Otto. And for the cow.

Don’t give me that bull. You want to let your wimpy jelly loaf soak up all my tasty grease. With that, Otto takes a brimming cheese-steak sandwich fr his grill and hefts it. It’s enormous. The steak slices are generous, and cheese and onions drip all over it.
My family opened this diner. My heritage is in this cheese-steak. If my nannouo, god rest, knew I put that on his grill... Otto shakes his head in disgust. Maya rolls her eyes at Otto. Leon smiles.

Alright, alright. I won’t ask again. Leon picks up his paper on the counter as he finishes his meal. He turns a page and sees a small photo in the metro section. A pretty girl, chic but over-done. Like a model.
I think I just saw her. Leon starts reading.  20 16.
She walked home from a club at 2:00 in the morning. Now they can’t find her. A model. She was celebrating a magazine cover. He takes a closer look. Holy shit: Now he remembers.
Maya. Look at this. I saw her the other night. Maya looks over at Leon, not sure what he means. Leon stands trying to remember what happened.
I tried to apologize, but she kept walking. Leon starts gathering his stuff. He leaves the deli wrap with the tofu, still open on Otto’s counter.
Where are you going?
To the police. I’1l show them the pictures. Maybe they’1l help.
Leon sits in a plastic chair. His photos of the Hip Girl are spread on the desk separating him from DETECTIVE LYNN HODGE, (late 40's) African-American. She points to the gangbangers.
These individuals ran off after you made your presence known by taking their picture.
I also pointed out that they were being filmed by a surveillance camera.
And they ran off toward the station entrance.  17.
Yes.
What station was this again? They've clearly been over this already. Leon controls his frustration.
The 14th Street station. Around midnight.
And Loretta ran off in the opposite direction. Toward the platform. You followed her. Saw her board?
Yes.
But then you left.
I missed the train. He gets uncomfortable.
I thought the photo might help with the timing and all that.
(nods ) So will the surveillance tape. Leon stands up, feeling embarrassed.
Sounds like you’re all set then.
You’d think she would’ve stuck around for a while. To thank you, for starters. From the looks of it, it didn’t seem like you were in a hurry. Holding out for the best shot I guess?
I lose myself sometimes.  18.
You sell your pictures, or just aspiring?
What’s that mean?
(who's he kidding) Loretta had a following. Some sheet may pay for them.
Look, I didn’t know her.
Why her then?
What do you mean?
If it’s not for money....do you follow women?
(pissed) No, I shoot everything.
So why’d you decide to follow her? If you weren’t stalking. Leon searches for an answer. Hodge holds his gaze.
I don’t know.
Trade secret? Okay, let’s stop for now. Hodge stands and gives Leon her card.
Call me if you come up with an answer. I’1l call you if there’s anything on those tapes that doesn’t jibe with your story.  21 19.

LEIGH and RANDLE COOPER, (30’s) healthy and sexy, well- dressed out-of-towners, sit next to TROY TALEVESKI, 30s, slick stockbroker type in pristine condition. Leigh looks around the car with obvious discomfort.
Don’t worry, Leigh. I ride this all the time. They erased all the graffiti about 20 years ago.
I don’t think that’s what makes Leigh nervous. Troy knows Randle is just as nervous as Leigh. He grins.
Loosen up, you two. I took you to a Broadway show. Now you’re getting the underbelly of the New York experience. The train comes to a stop, and the doors slide open.
Where is this place?

You don’t want to know. Troy smiles. He knows he's making the out-of-towners nervous. A group of Hip Hop KIDS stand up with their boom box. Leigh clutches the hand strap, cowering behind Randle. Tr bobs his head, trying to show the Kids he's down. The Hip Hop Kids simply ignore them and file off the trai As they clear the train, we see Mahogany sitting quietly the back. He is the only other person in the car. The tra moves on.
How bad can it be? Mahogany watches them, taking their measure.  20.
I know a restaurant critic who won't cover it. Randle raises his eyebrows at Leigh. She nervously smiles back at him. The train approaches another station, but rages by. Only Leigh notices.
Did we just miss a stop?

(to Troy, ignoring Leigh) Troy, we didn’t go on vacation to get shot in a ghetto. Leigh looks out the window. Then she looks at Mahogany. Now Mahogany just stares straight ahead. Leigh breathes deeply.

You told me you wanted to experience the culture, Randle. And that’s what I’m going to deliver. The train rolls down the track, lights flickering on and off. Blue sparks from the wheels dance against the tunnel walls. Leigh looks over at Randle, but he doesn’t return her gaz Mahogany suddenly lurches to his feet. He holds his arms behind his back, concealing something. Leigh watches him. The two guys face the other way.
If your not up for it we could go home. Leigh could cook us a romantic dinner for three.
What did I say about trying to charm my wife into bed.
(quietly) Randle? The guys ignore her.  21.
I wouldn't dream of it. But with anatomy like hers...
(joking) Watch it... Mahogany moves fast, taking long strides down the center the car. Something glints behind him, something metal.

Randle? RANDLE! Randle and Troy turn as Leigh screams, but Mahogany is up them, raising his massive arms. THUD! The steel hammer strikes Troy in the temple, knocki him to the floor. Mahogany spins gracefully, catching Randle in the gut wit a gigantic meat hook. The train lurches, knocking Leigh to the ground. Leigh screams as he lifts the meat hook up, hooking into Randle's rib cage. CLOSE on Randle's feet as Mahogany lifts him off the floo above Troy's body. The steel hammer finishes Randle with a sickening crunch. He falls to the ground next to his friend.

(whimpering) Why are you doing this? Mahogany pulls the meat hook out of Randle and turns, walking towards Leigh. Leigh scrambles away, knocking into his leather bag and falling to the floor. Butcher tools spill across the car. Leigh screams, trying to wrap her hand around a long CARVING KNIFE. Mahogany comes up behind her. And just as she is about to get a grip on the blade-- Mahogany grabs her ankles, pulling her backwards like a squealing calf.  22 A glint of metal above her head, the arc of the 22. steel hammer. THUD! She drops to the ground, legs twitching, silent. The lights flicker as the train clatters down the track.
22 Leon sits with Susan Hoff. She flips through a folder of Leon's latest prints and stops on one of the pictures of Loretta Dryer.
Talk to me about it.
(defying her) It is what it is.
This is the singer the police are looking for? What’d you tell them? She gives Leon a look like he has something to confess.
I just happened to be there. I shot what I saw.
So you were lucky? Or you saw something. Something no one else saw. A girl about to vanish. She gives him a look, like he knows more. Leon completely uncomfortable now.
I'm starting to see a point of view. Still tentative. But different. She looks into his eyes.
Not the “heart of the city.” But that was just bullshit. She now has a firm grip on his arm and moves in is close.  23
I have a group show up next. I can add a few of your shots. 23. Leon is ready to explode, but he doesn’t want to blow thi

It will be tight... but you have enough time to gather one or two more. Another strong one like this. INT. OTTO’S RESTAURANT - LATER - NIGHT Leon, Maya, and Jurgis, all a bit drunk, sit in booth, Maya almost in Leon’s lap. Leon tries to
(lifting his glass) I owe you. Both of you. You believed in this....
(interrupting) That’s because you’re great.
Hold on, I’ve got to deliver the show. She wants more work.
Don’t worry so much.
She's right. (smiling) Besides, now it’s not about the work, it’s about spin. Leon and Maya exchange glances.

I know this writer who covers the galleries for a bunch of the glossies. He’s an arrogant little dick-head but I’1l convince him you're the new Weegee and he’1l review your exhibition as if it was the second coming. 23 a corner be serious.  24.
Man, that’d be great. But if he’s going to write a good review, I want him to like the work.
Leon, he’s a fucking journalist. What does his opinion matter as long as he spells your name right?
(frowning) Jurgis.
Listen. Susan is mercurial, her friends are fickle. You need to stay ahead of her. We could give her a little scare.
Hold it. I don’t want to get ahead of anything.
Fine. But a friend of mine at Gagosian asked about you. You don’t have to meet her of course, if you don’t want to.
Do you know any art dealers that aren’t woman?
Plenty, but all the powerful ones are female. And usually quite attractive. He smiles at Maya, shining her on.
Did I ever tell you you're evil Jurgis? Jurgis smiles benignly. Maya puts her arm around Leon.
It may be a good evil though.  24 25 25.

Four in the morning. No one is out. Leon walks down an old street. Behind him, the Pershing Square subway. Ahead, closed store fronts, rundown residential hotels. He finds a bench and sits down. A shrug. What did he think he’d find at this hour? Even bad guys go to bed. He leans back, like he might doze off. Shuts his eyes. Then, very quietly at first, footsteps echo on a staircas They are coming up from the Pershing Square subway statio Camera up, Leon jumps up from the bench and ducks behind it. He lines up the subway entrance in his viewfinder. LEON’S POV: A large dark shape fills the frame, walking. POV: The camera lifts slightly, and we see an immense hea CLICK. Leon takes a shot. CLICK. He takes another. The man he catches is MAHOGANY. A big man in his 50’s wit a crisp white shirt, dark brown suit, and hair oiled back He holds a leather bag, and, eyes straight ahead, he walk alone along the sidewalk on the other side of the street. Leon is fascinated. He takes a few more shots until Mahogany crosses a street a half block away from Leon. Leon lets him walk another twenty feet before he follows. He keeps close to buildings, but Mahogany doesn’t look behind him. Mahogany moves very fast for a large man. In a few quick strides, Mahogany rounds a corner. Leon breaks into a run, stops at the corner, and then turns.

No one is on the street. Leon swings to his side and-- SLAMS INTO MAHOGANY. Mahogany’s bag dropping to the groun Leon's busted. He backs off, then stops, disarmed by the big man’s look. Did Mahogany know he had been followed? Mahogany stares right at him, inspecting him -- the cat who’s caught the mouse? Leon holds his camera down.  26 27 26.

Sorry Mister, I just wanted a picture of you. Sometimes I don’t even think about it. Leon notices Mahogany’s wrist, a TWISTED METAL BRACELET against his starched sleeves. A small moon and star. Then Leon’s eyes shift down to the bag on the ground. CLO on the engraved “Mahogany.” The bag is closed. Noting Leon’s look, Mahogany picks his leather bag up. We hear the clang of something metallic and heavy inside. Mahogany hefts the bag, and the clang is more pronounced. Leon looks up, reacting to the gesture, still nervous. He stares at the heavy bag and sees Mahogany’s large hand -- Is that a small spot of red on his wrist? Leon freezes. Leon takes a step back, suddenly afraid. Mahogany cracks a thin smile and shakes his head no. His gaze locked on Leon. A chill runs down Leon's spine. Mahogany turns and continues down the street. He reaches the stone staircase of a residential hotel and goes up. Leon stands there, as if he stepped in front of a bus. INT. LEON’S APARTMENT - DAY - LATER 26 Leon stands at his sink, fingering through a stack of prints. He pulls out all his shots of Loretta Dryer and looks them over. He sees something he hadn’t noticed: In his shot of the Homeless Man, there is a large man in a brown suit, seen from the back, carrying a leather satche Leon squints, then pulls out his last shot of the Hip Gir getting on the train. He sees the big hand holding the door. On the wrist, a thin line. A metal bracelet. Is that a moon, or just a smudge? No, just a smudge. Leon lowers the print, wondering about the connection. EXT. MAHOGANY’S RESIDENTIAL HOTEL - EVENING 27 Mahogany exits the building and walks down the street. Leon peeks out of a doorway. He waits a beat, then follow  28 29 30 31 32 27.
Leon, half a block behind, watches Mahogany approach a small, nondescript industrial building. He vanishes insid
Around the side of the building, a truck is parked at a loading dock. Leon walks up, doesn’t see anyone nearby. Leon jumps up onto the dock and looks into the building.

Leon sees CONVEYORS and a PACKING FLOOR running full tilt BUTCHERS in blue coveralls weigh and split giant beef carcasses hanging from METAL HOOKS. They slice through th bones and hack away the fat with SAWS and CLEAVERS. It’s a meat packing plant. Leon is amazed. He lifts up his camera to get a shot. CLICK! Intestines fall into a stainless steel cart. CLICK Blood is squeegeed through metal grates. CLICK! A bone sa sends a cloud of white dust in the air. The dust settles. Suddenly, at the rear, Mahogany emerges from a locker roo putting on blue coveralls. Leon jumps back a few feet. Mahogany, butcher’s apron on, reaches for a side of beef the size of a man. Without stopping, he wraps his arms around it in a gesture like a hug and lifts it like a pillow. He easily tosses it five feet onto a cutting rack Leon reacts, intimidated.
Leon waits by the corner, watching the entrance. Mahogany exits, bag in hand. Leon reacts and follows.

Mahogany stands back away from a group of riders on the platform. He seems to be watching them, measuring them.  33 28. Now we see Leon. Camera down, he’s even further back. Then a man in an overcoat, distracted, with a paper. An athletic guy. Back to Leon, wondering. On his gaze, the sound of a trai CLOSE ON the doors of a subway car as they open. The athletic guy enters. Mahogany follows right behind. Back to Leon, who steps forward. Suddenly -- -- A hand grabs his shoulder. A big STATION COP.
Hey, what’s this? The cop jerks Leon’s camera away from him.
What’re you taking pictures of? The hiss of the subway doors. Leon turns, they’re closed.

The passengers have thinned. Mahogany sits in the back, quietly observing the last few riders as they depart. A GUARDIAN ANGEL comes through from a rear car. He cocks finger and fires at Mahogany, who smiles back. The Guardian Angel walks to the front, watching as statio whiz by outside. He looks confused. The train is not slowing down. He leans down, looking out the window.

Why didn’t it stop - The Guardian Angel turns around. Mahogany is there holdin his stainless steel hammer. The hammer comes down. WHACK! The Guardian Angel hits the floor. INT. TRAIN DRIVER'S CAB - NIGHT -— CONTINUOUS 34 From the front cab, the DRIVER of the train can hear the sounds of a struggle coming from the car behind him. He slows the train a bit. And gets up from his seat. A thin man wearing a Transit Authority uniform, the Driver has a craggy and nicked face with the pallor of a man who spend little time in the sun. He opens the door to the car. The chaos in front of him i shocking. Two men struggling to kill each other, the Guardian Angel seems to be getting the upper hand. INT. TRAIN DRIVER'S CAB - NIGHT -— CONTINUOUS 36 The Driver, leaving the door open, calmly goes back into his cab. He reaches into a compartment and pulls out a small Glock automatic.

Clean up the mess. Get yourself patched up, you're not going to make it. INT. OTTO’S RESTAURANT -- NIGHT 38 Maya locks the front door of the diner and turns off some of the overhead lights. You asshole! How did you get in here? She hits his chest with her balled up fist.

No... Leon leans in close to Maya - reaching past her and slidi his hand across the surface of the counter. He looks at h hand - GREASE staining his finger tips. Then he feels something. A small dark red hole. So dark it’s almost black. It's dried blood, congealed around a small bullet hole. We pull back to see the head of the Guardian Angel. He’s hanging upside down. A dark shape hangs from the ceiling of an otherwise empty subway car. It trembles like a slender cocoon, shaking an writhing. But it is a body with its hands tied up. Leon sits at an old library cubicle, lit poorly by a soft amber overhead. He runs microfiche on an old-style fiche reader, with images hand-cranked on a white screen. Mahogany’s face appears in a bathroom mirror. He runs a comb through his hair, washes the comb, puts it on the sink. A splash of cologne on his cheeks. Mahogany crosses the empty street to the packing plant. A moment later, Leon emerges from the shadows. He sneaks around the back of the plant.

Leon climbs through a window onto a ledge slightly above the packing floor. His camera in his hand, he jumps to th ground. He sneaks forward, hiding behind a column. Not a rotting stench. Rather, a steam of blood drops. It almost overwhelms Leon, who feels the blood like a mis  36. Leon swings up his camera and looks through the lens: POV: A man in a white coat, clearly the boss, looks acros the floor at his crew, but he doesn’t say a word. THROUGH LENS: We track across the length of the productio line, seeing the conveyor chains which pull the lines along. Now we tilt down slightly, and a LARGE FACE fills the frame. MAHOGANY stares directly at us, eyes looking into the len Leon reacts. Mahogany has caught him. But maybe not. Mahogany turns away, walking out of frame. Leon follows him with the lens. POV: Mahogany stands at a tool bench and looks for something. He picks up a large knife and examines it. He twists it. Now Mahogany looks directly at us once more. He must see us. Leon jumps back, hyperventilating. Mahogany moves quickly across the floor, carrying the knife he got at the bench. Leon makes a quick break, running back along the inside wall. He backtracks to the window he came through, and he sees Two men in butcher coats blocking his path. Leon hides behind a column, unable to see the floor. He leans around the column. Mahogany stands just ten feet away. Leon moves back behind the column. He checks the window. The two men still block his path to the window. He waits. He leans out again and sees -- Mahogany is walking toward him. Leon sees a side hallway.  48 49 37.
Leon runs down the corridor, trying all the doors. He finds an open one and slips inside. It is a small meat locker.

Something hits Leon's forehead. He look up: a piece of meat swings above him. Leon almost drops. Mahogany grunts, pushing through the meat. Leon almost slips on the chain. Mahogany's shoes are closer. Then the shoes walk away. We hear steps, then none. Leon aches to let go of the chain, but he waits. No sound He takes a breath....and drops to the floor. No one there He turns -- -- And Mahogany is standing right before him. A few feet. The two men stare eye to eye for just a second. LEON’S APARTMENT -- SHOWER - LATER THAT AFTERNOON 51 Leon stands under the shower, the water pounding against his head. Leon scrubs his hands with a brush. Maya is busy with a table of patrons. Jurgis is at the counter, Otto’s at the grill. Leon comes in the front door, sits down next to Jurgis.
What happened to you today? No phone call, no interview?
Sorry Jurgis, I completely flaked.
Can I say something to you without you taking it the wrong way? You look like shit. Otto sets down Jurgis’s rare meat patty and a side salad.  39.
I’m fine.
You still look like shit. Leon stares down at Jurgis’s plate.
This is what you need. Nourishment. Real nourishment. You want some? Leon hesitates. Jurgis neatly cuts off a quarter of his burger with a kni and fork. Then he offers the piece to Leon.
You don’t have to feel bad about the cow. That cow lived in comfort and died in its sleep. Leon gives Jurgis an “as if” look.
C’mon, cows don’t worry about it. They know they’re not the top of the food chain.
How do you know we’re the top of the food chain?

Well, if we aren’t, they’d have to get past me. Then Leon opens the bun and take out the piece of beef. It’s cooked rare. A glistening trail of shiny grease runs down Leon’s finger. He experimentally licks it off. Then bites into the bloody beef. Jurgis and Otto trade a surprised look.
It melts, right? Like butter? Leon nods, his eyes glazed over for a moment. Then he swallows. He’s silent, wheels turning in his head.  53 40.
(to Otto) Otto, I’1l take one of my own.
Maya’s purse still hangs on her shoulder. She stands by the door, uncertain, as Leon reorganizes some photos. He doesn’t notice her.
You look like shit. Leon hangs up new photos on the wall. He turns around. Sh tosses her purse down.
You’re the second person who’s said that to me today.

But I’m the first person who cares. She steps closer, puts her hand on his shoulder. She push his hair away from his forehead. Then- She looks past him, at the photos on the wall. The photos are incredibly intense. ALL OF MAHOGANY AND THE MEAT PLAN
These aren’t for your show, are they? Maya pulls down a photo, tosses it, and walks away.
I asked you to stop this. And you agreed you would. Seeing her concern, he becomes more serious.
I think I know what’s going on. People disappear for all sorts of reasons. But it’s random, right? Maya gives him her sternest look.
In this area, by the subway, it’s not. There’s a cluster. (MORE )
LEON (cont'd) I checked. I think this guy is doing something. He takes people from the train and does something to them. At the meat plant.
Does what, Leon?
(carefully) He dismembers them. That’s why they aren’t found. Maya gives him a grim look, then she just laughs.

So they’re hamburger? (straight face) Otto had a bad batch last week, but he tossed it. Leon isn’t laughing. Now Maya watches him carefully. He lifts a folder from his table and pulls out a photo. CLOSE ON an older, weathered version of the meat plant.

Leon. Leon takes another sheet from the folder -- a clipping.
Enough.... She stands before him, puts a hand on his arm.
No, look what I found. The clipping is a copy of a newspaper article, an old one by its typeface.
I went to the TIMES. Their old stuff isn’t online yet. CLOSE ON an old headline and front page article --  42. April 11, 1896, Meat Company Butcher Cleared of Charges o

Cannibalism: “The city attorney has concluded his highly confidential investigation of claims by a company employe that local butcher engaged in murder and cannibalism... “The city attorney's office was never able to connect the butcher with any of the city’s many missing persons, nor establish where the allegedly ill-gotten meat went...”
(staring at it) It’s from a century ago.
That's right, but the same packing plant. A butcher was accused of murder.
A hundred years ago! What are you thinking? It’s the same guy? That’s he’s reincarnated?
No, just that it’s happened before. It’s too weird. It can’t be a coincidence. She can’t believe how stupid this sounds.
There are no vampires.
That’s not what I mean. Leon points back to the wall of Mahogany shots.
This guy is involved, I know it. I’ve seen him, I’ve looked in his eyes, it’s more than an instinct.
(interrupting) This is too stupid. Nothing is happening. Please stop. For me. Leon wraps his arms around her. She looks at the camera on the table. She touches his face and looks in his eyes.  43.

Come on, shoot something you like. She motions to the camera. She backs away from him. She leans against the sink. She unbuttons her blouse and skir Leon reaches for the camera. His face is serious. He gets up from the table. Backs away from her. Raises the camera to his eye. Maya’s skirt drops to the floor. She slips her feet out o them. She puts her head down. LEON’S POV: Her hair covering her face. Leon snaps a picture. She looks up to him. Her eyes meeting the lens. She's beautiful. Vulnerable. Leon snaps a picture. She pulls her shirt up over her head. Leon snaps a pictur She stands there. Nearly naked. In her underwear and her bra. Simple, refreshing to Leon. He snaps a picture- But this time - As the flash bounces off her skin. Again, a brief image of horror. A bri flash of Susan Hoff. Maya lets her bra fall from her shoulders, but she keeps herself covered. Looking right into her eyes this time, h snaps another picture. You were right, that’s what I wanted to say.  55 56 45. She gives him a warm kiss, but has to get back to work. S breaks the moment and heads off. Leon drops his shoulders and sits at the counter. He thinks about a cup of coffee. Then he turns to the door.

M&M's. You want some M&M's? Two SCRAWNY BLACK KIDS holding boxes of candy. Leon shake his head no, waving the kids away.

He bangs on the door.

Total silence. The train has stopped. Then- The sound of the doors opening. The top of a poorly-lit staircase with metal guard rails. Leon pulls himself to the last stair and takes a breath. His face and clothes are filthy, his beard unshaven. Focusing, he looks around. No blood around, just moisture He faces a plated metal door with old double locks. He grips the metal latch beneath the locks and pulls it hard The door swings open on a brightly-illuminated space, the light almost giving Leon a white-out. But he recognizes the noise right away. You're alive. Leon stays silent.
